div.p: The playground is closed until further notice due to the COVID-19 virus.
Click Alternative Method of Instruction (AMI) to find your students online classroom instruction.

School will be closed through April 30. An Alternate Method of Instruction (AMI) will be our students method of instruction. Any school events scheduled during this time have been postponed or cancelled.

p.em: As we are now on day two of our AMI plan hopefully you are able to find what you need. We are here to help. To streamline the process of answering your questions here are some contacts that can help you.

p.strong: If you have a question about food service:

div.p: Contact Mrs. Greene, mgreene@kingsville.k12.mo.us

p.strong: Questions about the instructional materials provided?

div.p: Contact your teacher(s) first, then Mr. Fleeman, jfleeman@kingsville.k12.mo.us
Contact Ms. Wallace, rwallace@kingsville.k12.mo.us
Contact the coach first, then Mrs. Morrison, amorrison@kingsville.k12.mo.us
Mrs. Collens, acollens@kingsville.k12.mo.us

p.strong: How can we stay updated on information from the school?

div.p: The school website, TextCaster, OneCall, Facebook, Email are all utilized. Instructions for setting up Texcast and Onecall accounts can be found at http://kingsville.k12.mo.us/

p.strong: Will we be able to take a chromebook or laptop from the school to use during the closure?

div.p: No, at this time we will not be able to do this. If completing the materials using the internet will be an issue you may request printed materials from your teacher(s).

p.strong: Can we get things out of our locker? Or classroom?

div.p: Right now this will only be for items that we feel are necessary, and on a case by case basis. Your teachers will strive to provide you with work you can complete at home without anything from school. If you have a question about picking something up you may contact your teacher or Mr. Fleeman.

p.strong: Can I get my band instrument?

div.p: Ms. Rhomberg and Mr. Fleeman are working on a plan for students to be able to pick up student instruments that belong to them personally. If the instrument belongs to the school it will need to stay at school during this closure.
District response to COVID-19

I know this is a difficult situation for our students and parents as well. Everyday I am concerned about academics and events students are missing. There are likely many questions that can’t be answered at the moment or at least until we get started with this temporary way of operating as a school district. I very much appreciate your patience as a valued student or parent. I also can not thank the entire staff enough for their commitment to be ready for any challenge that the coming days and weeks may bring in an effort to still prioritize the well-being and education of our students during this difficult time. Our educational team is working diligently to supply answers to the many questions that have arisen from COVID-19 and our school closure. Within the next few days the website will be updated to provide additional information, including the contacts for questions you may still have. At this time the buildings remain closed. Once again thank you for your patience.
Sincerely,
Lorna Warren
Kingsville R-1 Superintendent

Hello Kingsville Families.
With the recent announcement of the closure of our school we have teamed up with Holden School District and their food service provider Opaa! to be able to provide free daily breakfast, lunch, and supper to families in our district ages 0-18 years of age.
Lunch for the current day and breakfast for the following morning will be delivered by our school buses from Apple Bus Company, beginning at 10:30 a.m., or offered in drive-thru fashion at the front entrance between 10:30-11:30 am. Supper will be delivered by our buses, starting at 4:00 p.m., or offered for pick-up between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 5:00 p.m. Delivery services will follow normal bus routes, therefore, deliveries should be made to your bus stop or the end of your driveway within one hour of the delivery start time. In order to meet federal regulations, your child(ren) need to be present at pick-up or drop-off sites to receive the meals.
The following information regarding meal pick-up and delivery has been developed to meet federal regulations for the appropriate delivery of the free meals. A breakfast/ lunch menu for the next two weeks is attached and the dinner menu will become available soon. Parents/Guardians can request the free meal service by filling out the google form at this link: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdYLJsCM4SkT8467p4wKr26pHSUNK1_7w3Snw35NIQ-WoZ3Eg/viewform?usp=sf_link
If you do not have internet access, you may call the Kingsville School on Monday (23rd) or Tuesday (24th) between the hours of 1-3pm and give the following information:
*Parent/Guardian Name and Contact Information (phone #)
*Number of children needing meals (ages 0-18)
*Dates and meals you are requesting (Ex. March 24, Breakfast/Lunch & Supper)
*Indicate if you are picking up meals at the school or if you would like them delivered
*Delivery address
We will also take orders through our Facebook page if you are able to send the information through messenger.
We need the initial form filled out by Sunday (22nd) at 1:00 pm to begin services on Monday. Orders for the next day will need to be completed by 4:00 pm.
We want to make sure this information reaches all of our families during this difficult time. Please reach out to your neighbors and children's classmate's families to help us spread the word.
If you have any questions please contact Mandy Greene: mgreene@kingsville.k12.mo.us or Cindy Keller: ckeller@kingsville.k12.mo.us
Holden R-III Breakfast & Lunch Menu Supper Menu

div.h1: ALL spring practices have been postponed until further notice.
div.p: March 13, 2020
Kingsville R-1 Families:

Keeping students and staff healthy is a top priority for the Kingsville R-1 School District, especially in relation to the new coronavirus,COVID-19. In the past week alone, we have seen an increase across the country in the level of response to COVID-19.

As we receive updates from the Missouri Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE) regarding COVID-19 and its effect on schools, we will continue to evaluate the situation. At this point, our district schedule will remain the same with Spring Break concluding on Friday, March 20th and the return of students and staff on Monday, March 23rd.
If there is a need to close the school beyond the week of spring break we will be in contact with you through email, texts and the one call option.

p.strong: Preparing for the possibility of virtual learning

li.p: This is a rapidly-evolving situation and it is important to know that district plans could change or adjust as we receive new information from health, education and government officials. While school closures are not something we are predicting, it is important for all of us to prepare to implement home instruction if necessary.

If there is a need to close school beyond spring break we will contact you through email, texts and the one call option. Following that initial contact, please watch for an email from the district explaining the procedures we will implement for virtual learning or extended learning at home.
We will continue to provide you with information about our plans as we navigate this rapidly-evolving situation.

div.p: This should not be a time for panic - but rather a time for preparedness. We are all partners in safety, and it benefits all of us to work together to implement strategies to prevent and limit the spread of novel coronavirus.

Specific information related to COVID-19 can be found on the district website or you can go to the MO Department of Health and Senior Services website (https://health.mo.gov/living/healthcondiseases/communicable/novel-coronavirus/) or the Missouri Department of Elementary and Secondary Education
https://dese.mo.gov/communications/coronavirus-covid-19-information)
Your understanding and patience due to the fluidity of the situation are much appreciated.
Sincerely,
Lorna Warren
KIngsville R-1 Superintendent
Please follow the Corona Virus Information Link for news and update on the virus and how to prevent the spread of the virus.

Due to a scheduling conflict the date for Kindergarten Round-up will be moved to March 24, 2020 at 6:30 in the kindergarten classroom. Any child that will be age 5 by Aug. 1 is invited to join us for activities in the kindergarten classroom while parents / guardians will learn important information about kindergarten screening and enrollment.
Kindergarten screening will be April 3, 2020. You may sign up for a screening time at Round-up or call school to make an appointment.
Kingsville R-1 Families:
Keeping students and staff healthy is a top priority for the Kingsville R-1 School District, and the district has procedures in place to prevent the spread of illnesses and viruses.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's novel coronavirus (COVID-19) update on February 25 has provided school districts and communities guidance regarding preparation for the novel coronavirus.

Novel coronavirus is a virus strain that has spread in people since December 2019 and has caused severe illness and pneumonia. Symptoms are similar to the flu - cough, fever, shortness of breath and difficulty breathing. More information can be found at www.cdc.gov/coronavirus or health.mo.gov/coronavirus.
We are closely monitoring the coronavirus outbreak and reviewing information from the Johnson County Health Department, the Missouri Department of Health and the CDC.

We also took steps to address this rapidly-changing situation by having conversations this week about any additional proactive and preventative approaches we can take as we progress through the cold and flu season.
The district has taken or will take the following steps to ensure student and staff health:

li.p: The district will continue to communicate closely with county health professionals.
The nurse will continue to monitor and track student illnesses, and review CDC and state health department guidance.

The district will continue to use both routine cleaning methods and specialized decontamination equipment to provide extra disinfection efforts in classrooms and school buildings that have reported an uptick in illnesses.
The district is continuing to explore virtual school options for a scenario in which the health department recommends school cancellations.

The district will reinforce best practices to prevent the spread of flu, influenza and other viruses to staff and students. The number one way to stop the spread of illness remains to stay home if you are displaying any symptoms.

Respiratory viruses are transmitted from person to person when an infected person coughs or sneezes, or when a person touches something that has the flu virus on it and then touches his or her mouth, eyes or nose. While most of the population is at a greater risk of contracting seasonal influenza than coronavirus, it is essential that we partner to prevent the spread of all illnesses by embracing the following practices:

Staying home if you are sick with the flu or are presenting symptoms of the flu to prevent spreading it to others at school and in the workplace. If you believe you or your children are becoming ill with influenza-like symptoms (such as fever, cough, sore throat, body aches, headache, chills and fatigue), contact your local healthcare provider.
Practicing frequent hand washing using soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds. You may also use hand sanitizer when it is difficult to wash your hands.
Avoiding touching your mouth, nose and eyes because the virus can spread when your hands touch surfaces infested with germs.

Remembering to cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when coughing and sneezing. If a tissue is not available, sneezing or coughing into the upper portion of your shirt sleeve and avoid sneezing or coughing into your hands (which are more likely to touch surfaces and other people and spread the disease).

Not sharing drinks, water bottles, eating utensils or cell phones with others.Practicing “social distancing,” especially in the case of a pandemic. Stand at least three feet away from others if you or the other person is infected with the flu.
Ensuring that children and adults are fever-free for 24 hours without medication before returning to work or school.

If possible, getting a flu shot. How do you tell the difference between the common cold and the flu? If you have a stuffy nose, sneezing, sore throat and a hacking cough, you probably have a cold. If you have a high fever, extreme tiredness, a dry cough and severe headache, muscle and body aches, you probably have the flu.

Be assured that district staff take health concerns seriously and will be monitoring illness in schools, and that we will share additional information or guidance we receive from county, state and federal health professionals.
If we all work together and follow these important guidelines, we can keep our students, staff and community healthy.

div.p: School Makeup Days Will be 2/10, 2/17, 2/24, 3/2, 3/30, & 4/20.

In the unfortunate event that the weather warrants the school to have a late start, we want you to be prepared. A late start would be exactly 2 hours after the normal start time (9:50 am). All buses would be running 2 hours later than the normal school day. No breakfast would be served on those days. The school's daily schedule would continue to stay the same as far as class times are concerned. Please refer to Pages 7-8 of the student handbook for more information on late start days.

Please make sure, when using the Parent Portal to pay for school lunch, that you have selected the correct school year. It’s important to check this so that your student/s funds will be made available as soon as possible.
div.h3: Please remember to check the District Calendar for updates and the Athletic Calendar for activities updates. Any cancellations or makeup day changes will be posted to the calendar as soon as they are decided.

p.strong: The Media Release Form has changed this year. Parents need to specify in writing if they prefer that their student(s) not participate in video/photographic activities, have their student information released as part of “directory information”, participate in internet instructional activities (policies in handbook), and/or have their awards, honors, work, and photographs submitted to the media such as the newspaper, school website and Facebook page, etc. A complete copy of the Board Policies and Regulations is available for examination in the Superintendent’s office. If you have any questions please contact the building administrator.

img.alt: Congratulations to Brenden Shepard and Nathan Ory who qualified for Wrestling State!!!!!!!
Congratulations to Brenden Shepard and Nathan Ory who qualified for Wrestling State!!!!!!!

div.p: Congratulations to Brenden Shepard and Nathan Ory who qualified for Wrestling State!!!!!!!

The Kingsville Tigers and community came out to support Andy Sheer and his battle with cancer. Supporters wore their “Fight Like A Bear” shirts in honor of the event. Also that night, the Youth Tiger basketball teams and coaches were recognized for their hard work and dedication.

img.alt: The District will have a new notification system available for activities coming soon. The hope is to be able to extend that communication into classroom notifications as well. The app is called rSchool Today Activity Scheduler. Activities and practices will be listed along with bus times. Any changes made will immediately update to the that calendar. You can download this free app on your Android or IOS device. Once your have visited our districts rSchool Today webpage you can register to get notifications for certain events or All events. Those preferences will be determined by you. Any change in schedules will also result in a notification sent to your email or by text. You can download the app now and also register for notifications on our rSchool Today webpage . When on the Weekly View of events you can hover over Away Events to see the bus schedule. This is new to the district so it will take some time before all activities are posted for the entire year. But, there are several activities and practice times that are already available. We hope this new system will simplify communication between the school, parents,students, and community members. Our goal is to get information out to you and your student as quickly as possible.
